elements.content: A (4,8)-connected metal-organic framework has been constructed using an asymmetrical ligand based on dinuclear cadmium clusters as eight-connected nodes and mononuclear cadmium atoms as four-connected nodes, and it represents the flu topology network.
elements.clean_text: A (4,8)-connected metal-organic framework has been constructed using an asymmetrical ligand based on dinuclear cadmium clusters as eight-connected nodes and mononuclear cadmium atoms as four-connected nodes, and it represents the flu topology network.

elements.content: A (4,8)-connected metal-organic framework has been constructed using an asymmetrical ligand based on dinuclear cadmium clusters as eight-connected nodes and mononuclear cadmium atoms as four-connected nodes, and it represents the flu topology network.
elements.clean_text: A (4,8)-connected metal-organic framework has been constructed using an asymmetrical ligand based on dinuclear cadmium clusters as eight-connected nodes and mononuclear cadmium atoms as four-connected nodes, and it represents the flu topology network.

elements.content: Current interest in coordination polymers on the basis of the assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands is rapidly expanding because of their intriguing architectures and potential applications, although rational design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with unique structure and function still remains a long-term challenge. The topological analysis of MOFs has been a topical research area, which not only is an important tool for simplifying complicated compounds, but also plays an instructive role in the rational design of some functional materials with desired properties. To date, a variety of uninodal network topologies that are based on three-, four-, and six-connected topologies and so on have been realized so far. Examples of seven-, eight-, and twelve-connected metal-organic coordination frameworks are extremely rare because of the limited coordination numbers of metal centers and the steric hindrance issues of most commonly used organic ligands. On the other hand, some metal-organic frameworks with mixed-connected topologies have been reported, for example: Pt3O4, boracite, twisted boracite, PtS, rutile, pyrite, and anatase. However, there is an unfavorable lack of investigation on binodal high-connected structures. The (4,8)-connected flu (CaF2) topology frameworks are one of the most important and frequently encountered structure types in minerals. Nevertheless, only a few flu topology nets have been observed in metal-organic frameworks to date.
elements.clean_text: Current interest in coordination polymers on the basis of the assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands is rapidly expanding because of their intriguing architectures and potential applications, although rational design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with unique structure and function still remains a long-term challenge. The topological analysis of MOFs has been a topical research area, which not only is an important tool for simplifying complicated compounds, but also plays an instructive role in the rational design of some functional materials with desired properties. To date, a variety of uninodal network topologies that are based on three-, four-, and six-connected topologies and so on have been realized so far. Examples of seven-, eight-, and twelve-connected metal-organic coordination frameworks are extremely rare because of the limited coordination numbers of metal centers and the steric hindrance issues of most commonly used organic ligands. On the other hand, some metal-organic frameworks with mixed-connected topologies have been reported, for example: Pt3O4, boracite, twisted boracite, PtS, rutile, pyrite, and anatase. However, there is an unfavorable lack of investigation on binodal high-connected structures. The (4,8)-connected flu (CaF2) topology frameworks are one of the most important and frequently encountered structure types in minerals. Nevertheless, only a few flu topology nets have been observed in metal-organic frameworks to date.

elements.content: As shown above, it is a great challenge to achieve binodal high-connected MOFs in coordination chemistry. According to the previous literature, carboxylic acid and nitrogen-containing asymmetrical bridging ligands with different characters are excellent candidates for the construction of novel high-connected topological formworks. The carboxylate group may induce core aggregation by controlling the hydrolysis of metal salts with the aid of carboxylate ligands, and link these discrete clusters into an extended framework via its bridging ability. In addition, an asymmetric ligand benefits to the formation of mixed-connected frameworks because it may induce dissymmetric building blocks by coordinating to different metal centers or metal clusters with different coordination atoms (N and O). Taking these into account, we design to synthesize 4-(pyridin-3-ylmethoxy)benzoic acid (HL) as a nitrogen-containing asymmetric bridging carboxylic acid ligand (see the ). Fortunately, compound [Cd2L4(H2O)] (1) is isolated by hydrothermal methods (see the ). To the best of our knowledge, this represents the novel example of (4,8)-connected network based on mononuclear and dinuclear metal centers as nodes.
elements.clean_text: As shown above, it is a great challenge to achieve binodal high-connected MOFs in coordination chemistry. According to the previous literature, carboxylic acid and nitrogen-containing asymmetrical bridging ligands with different characters are excellent candidates for the construction of novel high-connected topological formworks. The carboxylate group may induce core aggregation by controlling the hydrolysis of metal salts with the aid of carboxylate ligands, and link these discrete clusters into an extended framework via its bridging ability. In addition, an asymmetric ligand benefits to the formation of mixed-connected frameworks because it may induce dissymmetric building blocks by coordinating to different metal centers or metal clusters with different coordination atoms (N and O). Taking these into account, we design to synthesize 4-(pyridin-3-ylmethoxy)benzoic acid (HL) as a nitrogen-containing asymmetric bridging carboxylic acid ligand (see the ). Fortunately, compound [Cd2L4(H2O)] (1) is isolated by hydrothermal methods (see the ). To the best of our knowledge, this represents the novel example of (4,8)-connected network based on mononuclear and dinuclear metal centers as nodes.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that there exist two CdII ions, four L ligands (La, Lb, Lc, and Ld) and one water molecule in the crystallographically independent unit. Cd1 is seven-coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands (see the ), whereas the Cd2 atom is ligated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (see the ) from two L ligands, two nitrogen atoms from other two L ligands and one water molecule. Of the four crystallographically independent L ligands, La adopts a bis(monodentate) bridging coordination fashion, Lb and Lc show monodentate-(bidentate-chelating) coordination mode, and Ld exhibits a different coordination mode (Figure ). So La, Lb, and Lc coordinate to one Cd1 ion and one Cd2 ion, and Ld links one Cd2 ion and two Cd1 ions, which form a double-core subunit with the Cd···Cd distance of 3.914 Å. On the basis of the above connection mode, each double-core subunit is coordinated by eight L ligands, and acts as a eight-connected node to link eight Cd2 atoms (see the ). Each Cd2 atom is bonded four L ligands and adopts a four-connected node to connect four double-core subunits (see the ). Lb and Lc ligands link Cd1 and Cd2 atoms to form one kind of chain (A = [Cd(L)]∞, L = Lb and Lc) along the crystallographic a axis. La and Ld ligands coordinate to Cd1 and Cd2 atoms to generate the double chain (B = [Cd2(L)2]∞, L = La and Ld). B double chains and A chains intersect at the double-core subunit with an angle of 53° to generate a 2D layered structure (Figure ). And then these interesting sheets are connected by sharing Cd2 atoms to form a 3D framework (see the ). If Cd2 atoms are considered as four-connected nodes (Figure a), and double-core subunits are considered as eight-connected nodes (Figure b), the overall structure of 1 is a 3D (4,8)-connected framework (Figure c). The Schläfli symbol for 1 is (412,612,84)(46)2. In addition, the coordination water molecule donates H-bonds (Table S2) to two carboxylate oxygen atoms, which further stabilize the 3D framework.

Of the four crystallographically independent L ligands, La adopts a bis(monodentate) bridging coordination fashion, Lb and Lc show monodentate-(bidentate-chelating) coordination mode, and Ld exhibits a different coordination mode (Figure ). So La, Lb, and Lc coordinate to one Cd1 ion and one Cd2 ion, and Ld links one Cd2 ion and two Cd1 ions, which form a double-core subunit with the Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance of 3.914 Å. On the basis of the above connection mode, each double-core subunit is coordinated by eight L ligands, and acts as a eight-connected node to link eight Cd2 atoms (see the ). Each Cd2 atom is bonded four L ligands and adopts a four-connected node to connect four double-core subunits (see the ). La and Ld ligands coordinate to Cd1 and Cd2 atoms to generate the double chain (B = [Cd2(L)2]∞, L = La and Ld). B double chains and A chains intersect at the double-core subunit with an angle of 53° to generate a 2D layered structure (Figure ). And then these interesting sheets are connected by sharing Cd2 atoms to form a 3D framework (see the ). If Cd2 atoms are considered as four-connected nodes (Figure a), and double-core subunits are considered as eight-connected nodes (Figure b), the overall structure of 1 is a 3D (4,8)-connected framework (Figure c). elements.content: (a, b) Ball-and-stick and schematic representations of 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. (c) A schematic diagram (OLEX) showing the (412,612,84)(46)2 network (green and pink balls represent four- and eight-connected nodes, respectively).
elements.clean_text: 3  (a, b) Ball-and-stick and schematic representations of 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. (c) A schematic diagram (OLEX) showing the (412,612,84)(46)2 network (green and pink balls represent four- and eight-connected nodes, respectively).

elements.content: Previous examples of (4,8)-connected frameworks are very rare, and it is reminiscent of the binary inorganic compound flu (CaF2), one of the most important and preferred structure for AB2 type compounds. In the simplified structure of 1, the mononuclear cadmium atoms replace F− ions as 4-connected nodes, and the dinuclear cadmium clusters replace Ca2+ ions as 8-connected nodes. Compared with the flu net, the 8-connected node of 1 is not a single atom but a dinuclear metal cluster, to be more precise, and this structure of compound 1 can be regarded as a decorated flu net. Up to date, only a few examples of fluorite topology have been observed in MOFs. For one of them, the (4,8)-connected nodes are simplified by tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)methane and tetranuclear cadmium−carboxylate clusters, respectively. Another two MOFs have been achieved by 4-connected metal ions of ZnII or CdII and an 8-connected ligand of 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)diphthalate. Here compound 1 is clearly different from them, and it is constructed from two kinds of metal centers (mononuclear cadmium atoms and dinuclear cadmium clusters) as different connected nodes.
elements.clean_text: Previous examples of (4,8)-connected frameworks are very rare, and it is reminiscent of the binary inorganic compound flu (CaF2), one of the most important and preferred structure for AB2 type compounds. In the simplified structure of 1, the mononuclear cadmium atoms replace F- ions as 4-connected nodes, and the dinuclear cadmium clusters replace Ca2+ ions as 8-connected nodes. Compared with the flu net, the 8-connected node of 1 is not a single atom but a dinuclear metal cluster, to be more precise, and this structure of compound 1 can be regarded as a decorated flu net. Up to date, only a few examples of fluorite topology have been observed in MOFs. For one of them, the (4,8)-connected nodes are simplified by tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)methane and tetranuclear cadmium-carboxylate clusters, respectively. Another two MOFs have been achieved by 4-connected metal ions of ZnII or CdII and an 8-connected ligand of 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)diphthalate. Here compound 1 is clearly different from them, and it is constructed from two kinds of metal centers (mononuclear cadmium atoms and dinuclear cadmium clusters) as different connected nodes.

elements.content: The luminescence properties of compound 1 and free ligand HL have been studied at room temperature (see the ). Compound 1 shows a maximum emission at 525 nm with a shoulder peak at 481 nm (λex = 460 nm), and HL displays a maximum emission at 510 nm with a shoulder peak at 467 nm (λex = 415 nm). The origin of the emission for compound 1 might be attributed to the intraligand transition of L anion. The shift relative to HL may be caused by the deprotonation and the coordination to the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by nonradiative decay. And compound 1 is very stable in air and the framework begins to decompose when heated to as high as 312 °C (see the ). In addition, the X-ray powder diffraction at different temperatures of compound 1 (XRPD) has been investigated (see the ).
elements.clean_text: The luminescence properties of compound 1 and free ligand HL have been studied at room temperature (see the ). Compound 1 shows a maximum emission at 525 nm with a shoulder peak at 481 nm (λex = 460 nm), and HL displays a maximum emission at 510 nm with a shoulder peak at 467 nm (λex = 415 nm). The origin of the emission for compound 1 might be attributed to the intraligand transition of L anion. The shift relative to HL may be caused by the deprotonation and the coordination to the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by nonradiative decay. And compound 1 is very stable in air and the framework begins to decompose when heated to as high as 312 °C (see the ). In addition, the X-ray powder diffraction at different temperatures of compound 1 (XRPD) has been investigated (see the ).

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared and characterized a (4,8)-connected framework using an asymmetrical ligand based on dinuclear cadmium clusters as eight-connected nodes and mononuclear cadmium atoms as four-connected nodes. The successful isolation of this species not only provides an intriguing example of chemical topology but also confirms the significant potential of constructing new binodal high-connected frameworks from different metal building blocks.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have prepared and characterized a (4,8)-connected framework using an asymmetrical ligand based on dinuclear cadmium clusters as eight-connected nodes and mononuclear cadmium atoms as four-connected nodes. The successful isolation of this species not only provides an intriguing example of chemical topology but also confirms the significant potential of constructing new binodal high-connected frameworks from different metal building blocks.

elements.content: Crystallographic data in CIF format; synthetic procedures, additional figures, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and IR for HL, XRD patterns, TGA, and luminescence spectra (PDF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic data in CIF format; synthetic procedures, additional figures, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and IR for HL, XRD patterns, TGA, and luminescence spectra (PDF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Crystal data for 1: triclinic, space group P1̅, M r = 1155.70, a = 9.1330(3) Å, b = 10.5120(3) Å, c = 24.7600(7) Å, α = 96.4920(10)°, β = 95.5780(10)°, γ = 97.8640(10)°, V = 2324.28(12) Å3, Z = 2, μ = 0.988 mm−1, D c = 1.651 Mg m−3, F(000) = 1164, T = 293(2) K, 14335 reflections collected, 10345 unique with R int = 0.0109, R1 = 0.0246, wR2 = 0.0609 (I > 2σ(I)), GOF = 1.035. Data collection was recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293K. Absorption corrections were applied using multi-scan technique. All the structures were solved by the direct method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as rigid groups. H atoms of water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps

metadata.title: A (4,8)-Connected Fluorite Topology Framework Based on Mononuclear and Dinuclear Metal Centers
